author: Jeff Whalley
title: Investment choices have changed a lot since the GFC
text:
ALMOST seven years after the global financial crisis, have Australian investors recovered from the shock?
Don’t bet on it, says Belinda Allen, economic and market research senior analyst at the Commonwealth Bank’s wealth management arm, Colonial First State.
Her side project, as she calls it, is Colonial’s Investor Insights series, which she kicked off in 2012 with the University of Western Australia’s business school.
They use Colonial data — from clients who don’t receive advice and accordingly make their own decisions — to draw a better picture of how investors behave during the investment cycle.
“We all assume the appetite for equities will go back to normal but I think the question is what is normal?” Ms Allen (pictured) says.
Among such clients’ portfolios, exposure to equities had fallen from 60 per cent to almost 40 per cent.
Ms Allen says appetite for risk “has permanently changed”, albeit in the context that people tend to have bigger mortgages and more savings.
“It’s about finding a new balance.”
Figures released by Colonial last month show that among many investors, particularly men aged 50 to 59, there has been a pronounced shift from shares to property — especially in Melbourne and Sydney.
Compiled by Colonial and the university, an index that measures appetite for equities relative to other investments showed a 32 per cent drop among that age group in the last six months of 2014.
Volatility has “prompted people to look at their portfolio”, she says.
“They are perhaps seeing the increasing returns in property. And, for a lot of people, for the last 25 years property has not done a lot of them wrong.”
The trend, she says, poses questions about investor expectations from the property market.
“How diversified is their portfolio if they are putting a lot of cash into property?
“What are the yields they are expecting on this over the long run?”
Ms Allen says the research more broadly shows the factors that influence investors are incredibly varied and constantly evolving.
Among them, she notes widespread expectations the US Federal Reserve will soon increase interest rates, potentially this year. “They haven’t hiked interest rates since the iPhone was released,” she says.
“That’s a good stat — to me that blows your mind a little bit. The world has changed for investors.”
